message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Journal of Argumentation in Context
Paper Abstract: The Journal of Argumentation in Context aims to publish high-quality papers about the role of argumentation in the various kinds of argumentative practices that have come into being in social life. These practices include, for instance, political, legal, medical, financial, commercial, academic, educational, problem-solving, and interpersonal communication. In all cases certain aspects of such practices will be analyzed from the perspective of argumentation theory with a view of gaining a better understanding of certain vital characteristics of these practices. This means that the journal has an empirical orientation and concentrates on real-life argumentation but is at the same time out to publish only papers that are informed by relevant insights from argumentation theory. These papers may also report on case studies concerning specific argumentative speech events.The journal aims to attract authors from various kinds of disciplinary background who are interested in studying argumentative practices in their fields of interest. In all cases, in papers published in the journal an interesting and revealing connection should be established between certain insights from argumentation theory and some particular context of argumentative practice.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's a comprehensive overview of argumentation based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning. With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, argumentation theory includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.(no content)Argumentation is one of four rhetorical modes (also known as modes of discourse), along with exposition, description, and narration.

An argument has one or more premises and one conclusion. In formal logic, classical logic is often used as the method of reasoning so that the conclusion follows logically from the assumptions or support.

## Types of Dialogue

Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation which are concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures. It also encompasses eristic dialogue, the branch of social debate in which victory over an opponent is the primary goal, and didactic dialogue used for teaching.

## Real-World Applications

Argumentation is a daily occurrence, such as in public debate, science, and law. Additionally, argument mining is a research area within the natural-language processing field, with the goal of automatically extracting and identifying argumentative structures from natural language text.

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Robert Alexy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Alexy"},{"title":"Natural Law and Natural Rights - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Law_and_Natural_Rights"},{"title":"Ja'fari school - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ja%CA%BDfari_jurisprudence"},{"title":"You Have the Right to Remain Innocent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/You_Have_the_Right_to_Remain_Innocent"},{"title":"Math on Trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Math_on_Trial"},{"title":"Argumentative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentative"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of legal argumentation:

## Definition and Scope

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning, with historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric that includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.

## Components of Arguments

The essential components of practical arguments are claim, ground, and warrant, while qualifier, backing, and rebuttal may not be needed in some arguments. For example, in legal reasoning, to move from a ground such as "I was born in Bermuda" to a claim "I am a British citizen," a person must supply a warrant with the statement "A man born in Bermuda will legally be a British citizen."

## Legal Opinions

A judicial opinion or legal opinion is in certain jurisdictions a written explanation by a judge or group of judges that accompanies an order or ruling in a case, laying out the rationale (justification) and legal principles for the ruling.

## Theoretical Contributions

One of the most influential theorists in this field is Robert Alexy, a jurist and legal philosopher who received his J.D. in 1976 with the dissertation A Theory of Legal Argumentation.(no content)Alexy's theory of argumentation puts him very close to legal interpretivism.

## Applications in Courts

Mathematical and statistical reasoning is used in legal argumentation, as examined in scholarly work analyzing how numbers get used and abused in the courtroom.

Links: [{"title":"Political argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_argument"},{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argumentative turn - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentative_turn"},{"title":"Debate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debate"},{"title":"The Argument (magazine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Argument_(magazine)"},{"title":"Argumentum ad populum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_from_popularity"},{"title":"Gary Woodward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Woodward"},{"title":"Semantic argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_argument"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"},{"title":"Political question - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_question"}]

I found search results for "Political argumentation." Here's what I discovered:

## Overview

A political argument is an instance of a logical argument applied to politics.(no content)Political arguments are used by academics, media pundits, candidates for political office, and government officials.(no content)Political arguments are also used by citizens in ordinary interactions to comment on and understand political events.

## Key Characteristics

More often than not, political arguments tend to be circular, repeating the same facts as premises under perhaps slightly different guises.(no content)The political argument should be distinguished from propaganda, in that propaganda has little or no structure or the rationale, if it exists, is egregiously fallacious.(no content)Political argument though is not generally a purely intellectual activity, since it may also serve the strategic goal of promoting a political agenda.

## Purpose and Context

The purpose of an argument is usually to sway belief.(no content)In a democracy, though, political argument is particularly important, since there is a direct relationship between the beliefs of citizens and the structure of power.

The search results also highlight that much political argument concerns issues of taxation and government spending, and provide The Federalist Papers as a classic example of political arguments arguing in favor of ratification of the American constitution.

Links: [{"title":"Medical decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_decision-making"},{"title":"Medical Decision Making (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_Decision_Making_(journal)"},{"title":"Shared decision-making in medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared_decision-making_in_medicine"},{"title":"Society for Medical Decision Making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Medical_Decision_Making"},{"title":"Surrogate decision-maker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrogate_decision-maker"},{"title":"Decision aids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_aids"},{"title":"Medical algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_algorithm"},{"title":"Therapeutic privilege - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therapeutic_privilege"},{"title":"Ewout W. Steyerberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ewout_W._Steyerberg"},{"title":"Gello Expression Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gello_Expression_Language"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of medical decision making:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Medical decision-making is a cognitive process for selecting a course of action in the context of health or medical diagnosis and treatment.

## Shared Decision-Making

Decision making in health care is a joint process where clinicians and patients come together to make shared health decisions, using the best available evidence along with the patient's values and preferences.(no content)This approach recognizes that decisions should incorporate both clinical evidence and patient values.

## Decision Aids

Decision aids provide people with a greater understanding of their medical treatment options and empower them to participate in their own health decision-making. Supplementing patient-education consultations with decision tools improves people's knowledge about the risks and benefits of a procedure or medication and may help them make decisions that are in line with their personal values.

## Medical Algorithms

A medical algorithm is any computation, formula, statistical survey, nomogram, or look-up table, useful in healthcare. Medical algorithms include decision tree approaches to healthcare treatment and also less clear-cut tools aimed at reducing or defining uncertainty.(no content)The intended purpose of medical algorithms is to improve and standardize decisions made in the delivery of medical care, with algorithm automation intended to reduce potential introduction of errors.

## Organizations and Research

Medical Decision Making is a peer-reviewed academic journal that publishes papers in the fields of decision-making and medical informatics. It was established in 1981 and is currently published by SAGE Publications on behalf of the Society for Medical Decision Making.

Supplementing patient-education consultations with decision tools improves people's knowledge about the risks and benefits of a procedure or medication and may help them make decisions that are in line with their personal values.

## Medical Algorithms

A medical algorithm is any computation, formula, statistical survey, nomogram, or look-up table, useful in healthcare. Medical algorithms include decision tree approaches to healthcare treatment and also less clear-cut tools aimed at reducing or defining uncertainty.(no content)The intended purpose of medical algorithms is to improve and standardize decisions made in the delivery of medical care, with algorithm automation intended to reduce potential introduction of errors.

## Organizations and Research

Medical Decision Making is a peer-reviewed academic journal that publishes papers in the fields of decision-making and medical informatics. It was established in 1981 and is currently published by SAGE Publications on behalf of the Society for Medical Decision Making.

Walton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_N._Walton"},{"title":"Chaïm Perelman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaïm_Perelman#:~:text=Perelman and Olbrechts-Tyteca rely in particular for their theory,greatest adherence according to an"},{"title":"Charles Arthur Willard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Arthur_Willard"},{"title":"Appeal to the stone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentum_ad_lapidem"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of argumentation theory:

## Definition and Scope

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning.(no content)With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, it includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion, and studies rules of inference, logic, and procedural rules in both artificial and real-world settings.

## Historical Development

Argumentation theory had its origins in foundationalism, a theory of knowledge in philosophy, which sought to find the grounds for claims in the forms (logic) and materials (factual laws) of a universal system of knowledge. However, philosopher Chaïm Perelman, together with Lucie Olbrechts-Tyteca, introduced the French term "la nouvelle rhetorique" in 1958 to describe an approach to argument which is not reduced to application of formal rules of inference.

## Key Areas of Study

Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures, as well as eristic dialogue (where victory over an opponent is the primary goal) and didactic dialogue used for teaching.(no content)An argumentation scheme is a template that represents a common type of argument used in ordinary conversation, presenting a type of connection between premises and a conclusion in an argument.(no content)Argumentation is a daily occurrence, such as in public debate, science, and law.

Here are the search results for "Problem solving":

## Overview

Problem solving is the process of achieving a goal by overcoming obstacles, a frequent part of most activities.(no content)Problems range from simple personal tasks (e.g. how to turn on an appliance) to complex issues in business and technical fields.

## Types and Approaches

There are two different types of problems: ill-defined and well-defined; well-defined problems have specific end goals and clearly expected solutions, while ill-defined problems do not.(no content)There are many specialized problem-solving techniques and methods in fields such as science, engineering, business, medicine, mathematics, computer science, philosophy, and social organization.

## Problem-Solving Process

The process starts with problem finding and problem shaping, in which the problem is discovered and simplified. The next step is to generate possible solutions and evaluate them. Finally a solution is selected to be implemented and verified.

## Cognitive Aspects

The mental techniques to identify, analyze, and solve problems are studied in psychology and cognitive sciences, and mental obstacles that prevent people from finding solutions include confirmation bias, mental set, and functional fixedness.

The search results provide comprehensive information about problem-solving across various disciplines and domains. For more detailed information about specific topics, you can explore the source links directly.

I've completed the web search for "Academic debate." Here are the key findings:

## What is Academic Debate?

Debate is a process that involves formal discourse, discussion, and oral addresses on a particular collection of topics, often with a moderator and an audience.(no content)In a debate, arguments are put forward for opposing viewpoints.

## Educational Benefits

Research shows that students who participated more in debate were likely to graduate, perform better academically and have a better GPA vs student who didn't.

## Academic Debate Formats

The structure of parliamentary debate has influenced academic debate formats, including the Asian Parliamentary style which includes two teams of three speakers who engage in speeches and is widely practiced in Asian Countries such as Japan, Malaysia and Taiwan.(no content)Impromptu debate is a type of formalized academic debate that is practised at high schools and universities, generally in tandem with other, more serious forms of debate.

## Historical Context

Debates have been conducted for educational and recreational purposes, usually associated with educational establishments and debating societies.

I've completed the web search for "Academic debate." Here are the key findings:

## What is Academic Debate?

Debate is a process that involves formal discourse, discussion, and oral addresses on a particular collection of topics, often with a moderator and an audience.(no content)In a debate, arguments are put forward for opposing viewpoints.

## Educational Benefits

Research shows that students who participated more in debate were likely to graduate, perform better academically and have a better GPA vs student who didn't.

## Academic Debate Formats

The structure of parliamentary debate has influenced academic debate formats, including the Asian Parliamentary style which includes two teams of three speakers who engage in speeches and is widely practiced in Asian Countries such as Japan, Malaysia and Taiwan.(no content)Impromptu debate is a type of formalized academic debate that is practised at high schools and universities, generally in tandem with other, more serious forms of debate.

## Historical Context

Debates have been conducted for educational and recreational purposes, usually associated with educational establishments and debating societies.

Links: [{"title":"Interpersonal communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_communication"},{"title":"Category:Interpersonal communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Interpersonal_communication"},{"title":"Intrapersonal communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intrapersonal_communication"},{"title":"Identity management theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_management_theory"},{"title":"Communication theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_theory"},{"title":"Haptic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haptic_communication"},{"title":"Category:Communication theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Communication_theory"},{"title":"Communication in small groups - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_in_small_groups"},{"title":"Models of communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Models_of_communication"},{"title":"Salience (language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salience_(language)"}]

## Interpersonal Communication

Based on the search results, here's an overview of interpersonal communication:

### Definition

Interpersonal communication is an exchange of information between two or more people. More broadly, it is also an area of research that seeks to understand how humans use verbal and nonverbal cues to accomplish several personal and relational goals.

### Scope and Settings

Interpersonal communication is often defined as communication that takes place between people who are interdependent and have some knowledge of each other: for example, communication between a son and his father, an employer and an employee, two sisters, a teacher and a student, two lovers, two friends, and so on.(no content)Interpersonal communication can take place in face-to-face settings, as well as through platforms such as social media.

### Key Research Areas

Interpersonal communication research addresses at least six categories of inquiry: 1) how humans adjust and adapt their verbal communication and nonverbal communication during face-to-face communication; 2) how messages are produced; 3) how uncertainty influences behavior and information-management strategies; 4) deceptive communication; 5) relational dialectics; and 6) social interactions.

### Influencing Factors

Factors such as one's self-concept and perception do have an impact on how humans choose to communicate. Factors such as gender and culture also affect interpersonal communication.

Web search results for query: "Rhetoric"

Links: [{"title":"Rhetoric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetoric"},{"title":"Digital rhetoric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_rhetoric"},{"title":"Rhetorical criticism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorical_criticism"},{"title":"Rhetorical question - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorical_question"},{"title":"Rhetoric of social intervention model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetoric_of_social_intervention_model"},{"title":"Rhetorical device - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorical_device"},{"title":"Boylston Professorship of Rhetoric and Oratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boylston_Professorship_of_Rhetoric_and_Oratory"},{"title":"Rhetoric of health and medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetoric_of_health_and_medicine"},{"title":"Rhetoric (Aristotle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetoric_(Aristotle)"},{"title":"Universal rhetoric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_rhetoric"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about rhetoric:

## Definition

Rhetoric is the art of persuasion.(no content)As an academic discipline within the humanities, rhetoric aims to study the techniques that speakers or writers use to inform, persuade, and motivate their audiences.

## Historical Context

It is one of the three ancient arts of discourse (trivium) along with grammar and logic/dialectic.(no content)The five canons of rhetoric, or phases of developing a persuasive speech, were first codified in classical Rome: invention, arrangement, style, memory, and delivery.(no content)From Ancient Greece to the late 19th century, rhetoric played a central role in Western education and Islamic education in training orators, lawyers, counsellors, historians, statesmen, and poets.

## Scope and Modern Applications

Although some have limited rhetoric to the specific realm of political discourse, to many modern scholars it encompasses every aspect of culture.(no content)Rhetoricians have studied the discourses of a wide variety of domains, including the natural and social sciences, fine art, religion, journalism, digital media, fiction, history, cartography, and architecture, along with the more traditional domains of politics and the law.

## Key Concepts

A rhetorical device—also known as a persuasive or stylistic device—is a technique that an author or speaker uses to convey meaning to a listener or reader, with the goal of persuading them to consider a topic from a particular point of view. These devices aim to make a position or argument more compelling by using language designed to evoke an emotional response or prompt action.
